description: Magnificent Victorian cemetery with Gothic chapel & restored & ruined lodge. One of London's wildest cemeteries. Part restored with the help of a lottery grant. 52 acres of woodland, with bats, owls, foxes & squirrels. Grade II*  landscape.

designers.architect: James Bunstone Bunning and Thomas Little

events.notes: Please let us know if you plan to visit. Doing so allows the venue to plan ahead and you will be notified by email about any changes to the programme that might affect your visit.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: Perhaps the least known, but most attractive, of the great Victorian Cemeteries of London. Consecrated in 1840, it is one of the seven great Victorian cemeteries established in a ring around the outskirts of London. It contains examples of the magnificent monuments erected in memory of the most eminent citizens of the day, which contrast sharply with the small, simple headstones marking common, or public, burials. Its formal avenue of towering limes and the Gothic gloom of the original Victorian planting gives way to paths which recall the country lanes of a bygone era.

factsheet.heading: Buildings
paragraphs: The imposing cemetery entrance gates are Grade II listed as are the restored West Lodge and the ruined East Lodge. The East Lodge is currently undergoing full restoration. The Anglican chapel is not normally open to the public and is also Grade II listed. The crypt under the chapel will be open to visitors. The smaller Dissenters chapel was destroyed by bombing in WWII.

factsheet.heading: Tours and walks
paragraphs: On both Saturday 9 September and Sunday 10 September, 20 minute guided visits to the crypt will take place at 13.30; 14.15; 15.00; 15.45.  One hour 30 minutes long guided cemetery tours will take place at 14.00 and 15.00.

factsheet.heading: Publications
paragraphs: A wide range of publications about the cemetery and those interred there and postcards will be available and are very moderately priced.

travel_info: Tube: New Cross Gate, New Cross

name: Nunhead Cemetery
